evidence: In coherent, or Rayleigh scattering, the photon is deflected at a very small angle, but its energy remains the same.
The photon simply passes through the material unchanged.
The photon is completely absorbed by an atom.
The photon is deflected at a very small angle, but its energy remains the same.
The photon collides with an outer-shell electron and transfers part of its energy to it.
The photon gives rise to absorption contrast.
Compton scattering dominates at higher energies and contributes to image noise and radiation dose.
